title: A Sample of Nearby Isolated Dwarf Galaxies: A First Look at the Mass Function of Field Dwarfs
comment: Submitted to ApJ and posted after responding to referee report. Comments welcome
summary: We present the results of the Exploration of Local VolumE Survey - Field (ELVES-Field), a survey of the dwarf galaxies in the Local Volume (LV; $D<10$ Mpc) over roughly $3,000$ square degrees, focusing on the field dwarf population. Candidates are detected using a semi-automated algorithm tailored for low surface brightness dwarfs. Using tests with injected galaxies, we show the detection is $50\%$ complete to $m_g\sim20$ mag and $M_\star \sim 10^6$ $M_\odot$. Candidates are confirmed to be true nearby dwarfs through distance measurements including redshift, tip of the red giant branch, and surface brightness fluctuations. We identify isolated, field dwarfs using various environmental criteria. Over the survey footprint, we detect and confirm 95 LV dwarfs, 44 of which we consider isolated. Using this sample, we infer the field dwarf mass function and find good agreement at the high-mass end with previous redshift surveys and with the predictions of the IllustrisTNG simulation. This sample of isolated, field dwarfs represents a powerful dataset to investigate aspects of small-scale structure and the effect of environment on dwarf galaxy evolution.

AI.tldr: ELVES-Field survey identifies 95 nearby dwarf galaxies within 10 Mpc, including 44 isolated ones, enabling study of field dwarf mass function and environmental effects on dwarf evolution.
AI.motivation: To systematically study the field dwarf galaxy population in the Local Volume (D<10 Mpc), focusing on isolated dwarfs to understand small-scale structure and environmental effects on dwarf galaxy evolution, which complements previous studies focused on group environments.
AI.method: Semi-automated algorithm tailored for low surface brightness dwarf detection over ~3,000 square degrees; completeness verified through injected galaxy tests (50% complete to m_g~20 mag, M_*~10^6 M_sun); confirmation via multiple distance measurement techniques (redshift, TRGB, SBF); isolation determined using various environmental criteria.
AI.result: Detected and confirmed 95 Local Volume dwarfs, with 44 classified as isolated; inferred field dwarf mass function shows good agreement at high-mass end with previous redshift surveys and IllustrisTNG simulation predictions.
AI.conclusion: The ELVES-Field survey provides a powerful dataset of isolated field dwarfs for investigating small-scale structure and environmental effects on dwarf galaxy evolution, with mass function consistent with simulations and previous observations at high masses.

title: MIDIS: The identification of deep MIRI-red sources as candidates for extreme Balmer-break and line emitting galaxies at high-z
summary: We investigate the detection and nature of 5.6~μm MIRI-red sources in the MIRI Deep Imaging Survey (MIDIS), covering 2.4~arcmin$^2$ in the Hubble Ultra Deep Field. MIDIS is the deepest JWST/MIRI survey to date, probing faint limits and enabling studies of rare high-redshift galaxy populations. We define MIRI-red sources as those detected at 5$σ$ significance in MIRI/F560W with red colors: $m_{\rm F444W} - m_{\rm F560W} \ge 0.5$. Using an empirical methodology, we estimate the purity and completeness of MIRI detections and find that a 5-sigma detection at 28.75 mag has a purity of 92\% and completeness of 54\%. We identify seven MIRI-red galaxy candidates, including an F115W dropout consistent with a high-redshift galaxy candidate. We explore possible physical origins for the MIRI-red population, including active galactic nuclei, dust-obscured galaxies, extreme emission-line galaxies, evolved stellar populations, and Little Red Dots (LRDs). Given the proximity of the F444W and F560W filters and the depth of MIDIS, MIRI-red galaxies are consistent with emission-line galaxies with $EW_0(Hα) \ge 750$ Å or $EW_0(Hβ+ [OIII]) \ge 600$ Å, or high-redshift Balmer breaks of at least 1.6. We also discuss an extreme MIRI-red galaxy undetected in F444W, a potential MIRI-only source, for which we derive $EW_0(Hα) \sim 6000$ Å and $EW_0(Hβ+ [OIII]) \sim 4000$ Å, or high-$z$ LRD analogs with Balmer breaks of 6.3. Finally, we find fewer MIRI-red detections than expected from extrapolations of the H$α$ or H$β$+[OIII] line luminosity functions, consistent with previous deep searches, while the absence of $z>10$ LRD candidates agrees with theoretical expectations for the MIDIS volume.

AI.tldr: MIDIS survey identifies 7 MIRI-red galaxy candidates with extreme emission lines or high-redshift Balmer breaks, finding fewer than expected from luminosity function extrapolations.
AI.motivation: To investigate the detection and nature of 5.6μm MIRI-red sources in the deepest JWST/MIRI survey to date, enabling studies of rare high-redshift galaxy populations.
AI.method: Used MIDIS data covering 2.4 arcmin² in HUDF, defined MIRI-red sources as 5σ detections in F560W with red colors (m_F444W - m_F560W ≥ 0.5), applied empirical methodology to estimate purity/completeness, and explored physical origins through emission line equivalent widths and Balmer breaks.
AI.result: Found 7 MIRI-red galaxy candidates including an F115W dropout; estimated 92% purity and 54% completeness at 28.75 mag; MIRI-red galaxies consistent with extreme emission-line galaxies (EW₀(Hα) ≥ 750Å or EW₀(Hβ+[OIII]) ≥ 600Å) or high-z Balmer breaks ≥1.6; identified one extreme MIRI-only source with EW₀(Hα) ∼6000Å; found fewer detections than expected from line luminosity function extrapolations.
AI.conclusion: MIRI-red sources in MIDIS represent extreme emission-line galaxies or high-redshift objects with strong Balmer breaks; the survey depth enables detection of rare populations but finds fewer than predicted, consistent with previous deep searches and theoretical expectations for the survey volume.

title: Lithium as a probe of stellar and galactic physics
comment: Manuscript submitted to Annual Reviews of Astronomy and Astrophysics for Volume 64. This is the authors version, which includes more references than the final version that will only become available from ARAA webpage. This version also contains the supplementary material that will be only available on line
summary: Lithium plays a unique role in astrophysics, as it is a powerful diagnostic for the physics and evolution of low-mass stars, Galactic archaeology, and cosmology. We review the Li observations in stars at different phases of their evolution, the strengths and the limitations of the current theoretical stellar models to explain the Li abundance data, our understanding of the Li sources and of the evolution of Li through- out the Galactic history. Key takeaways from the current state of the research in the field are: 1) Stellar evolution models accounting for fundamental transport processes of chemical species and angular momentum hold the promise of providing a common stellar Li depletion explanation to the Li abundance patterns observed in all Galactic stellar populations, including the dip and the plateau(s). 2) Novae are most probably the main source of Li in the Galaxy, on observational (but not yet theoretically established) grounds. 3) Radial migration of stars in the Galactic disk holds the key to understand many aspects of the Li evolution in the Milky Way.

AI.tldr: Lithium serves as a key astrophysical diagnostic; stellar models with transport processes can explain Li depletion patterns across Galactic populations, novae likely dominate Galactic Li production, and radial migration is crucial for understanding Milky Way Li evolution.
AI.motivation: Lithium's unique diagnostic power for low-mass stellar physics, Galactic archaeology, and cosmology motivates comprehensive review of observational data, theoretical models, and evolutionary understanding of Li abundance patterns across stellar populations and Galactic history.
AI.method: Review approach synthesizing Li observations across stellar evolutionary phases, evaluating strengths/limitations of theoretical stellar models, analyzing Li sources, and examining Li evolution throughout Galactic history with focus on transport processes and migration effects.
AI.result: Three key findings: 1) Stellar evolution models incorporating chemical/angular momentum transport can explain Li depletion patterns (dip and plateau) across all Galactic populations; 2) Novae are likely the dominant Galactic Li source based on observational evidence; 3) Radial migration in the Galactic disk is essential for understanding Milky Way Li evolution.
AI.conclusion: Lithium remains a powerful astrophysical diagnostic; comprehensive understanding requires integration of transport processes in stellar models, recognition of novae as primary Li producers, and consideration of radial migration effects to explain observed abundance patterns throughout Galactic history.

title: Interstellar Formation of Thioethanal (CH$_{3}$CHS). Gas-Phase and Ice-Surface Mechanisms involving Secondary Sulfur Products
summary: The formation pathways of sulfur-bearing species in the interstellar medium are crucial to understand astrochemical processes in cold molecular clouds and to gain new insights about the sulfur budget in these regions. We aim to explore the recently detected, thioethanal (CH$_{3}$CHS) formation mechanisms from thioethanol (CH$_{3}$CH$_{2}$SH) as a precursor in addition to secondary sulfur products. The electronic structure methods and density functional theory for both gas-phase and ice-grain surface environments is employed. To mimic interstellar ice-mantles, we use medium (W6) and large amorphized (W22) water clusters as implemented in Binding Energy Evaluation protocol. A barrierless formation mechanism for CH$_{3}$CHS under low-temperature interstellar conditions is identified, in the gas phase. Surface environments modulate activation barriers in a site-specific manner, elucidated through both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal initiated surface reaction pathways. Compared to oxygen analogs, sulfur chemistry enables alternate pathways due to weaker S-H bonding, with a competing route forming ethane-1,1-di-thiol (CH$_{3}$CH(SH)SH), on the ice-grain surface, potentially reducing CH$_{3}$CHS yields. The first accurate binding energy for thioethanol on water ice is also reported, confirming its greater volatility than ethanol. The proposed mechanism offers a tentative hypothesis for the apparent mutual exclusive detections of the CH$_{3}$CH$_{2}$SH and CH$_{3}$CHS in TMC-1, Orion, and Sgr B2(N), that further requires validation through quantitative astrochemical modeling and also to distinguish this chemical differentiation from observational sensitivity limitations. These qualitative findings highlight the multifaceted chemical behavior of sulfur-bearing organics in the interstellar medium and support CH$_{3}$CH(SH)SH as promising astro-chemical targets.

AI.tldr: Study explores formation pathways of thioethanal (CH₃CHS) from thioethanol (CH₃CH₂SH) in interstellar environments using quantum chemical methods, identifying barrierless gas-phase formation and competing surface reactions on water ice.
AI.motivation: To understand sulfur-bearing species formation in interstellar medium, particularly thioethanal formation mechanisms, and gain insights into sulfur budget in cold molecular clouds, addressing the apparent mutual exclusive detections of CH₃CH₂SH and CH₃CHS in astronomical sources.
AI.method: Employed electronic structure methods and density functional theory for gas-phase and ice-grain surface environments. Used medium (W6) and large amorphized (W22) water clusters to mimic interstellar ice-mantles via Binding Energy Evaluation protocol. Analyzed both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal surface reaction pathways.
AI.result: Identified barrierless formation mechanism for CH₃CHS in gas phase under low-temperature conditions. Surface environments modulate activation barriers site-specifically, with competing route forming ethane-1,1-di-thiol (CH₃CH(SH)SH) on ice-grain surfaces, potentially reducing CH₃CHS yields. Reported first accurate binding energy for thioethanol on water ice, confirming its greater volatility than ethanol.
AI.conclusion: Proposed mechanism offers tentative hypothesis for mutually exclusive detections of CH₃CH₂SH and CH₃CHS in TMC-1, Orion, and Sgr B2(N). Sulfur chemistry enables alternate pathways due to weaker S-H bonding compared to oxygen analogs. Findings highlight multifaceted chemical behavior of sulfur-bearing organics and support CH₃CH(SH)SH as promising astrochemical target requiring further validation through quantitative modeling.

title: MUSEQuBES: Probing Anisotropies in Gas and Metal Distributions in the Circumgalactic Medium
comment: Submitted to ApJ. Comments are welcome
summary: We investigate the azimuthal dependence of H I and O VI-bearing gas in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) of 113 isolated galaxies in the redshift range 0.12 < z < 0.75, including 91 new measurements from the MUSE Quasar-fields Blind Emitters Survey (MUSEQuBES). The H I covering fraction (k_HI) within the virial radius (Rvir) of low-mass (7 < log10(M*/Msun)< 9) galaxies, for a threshold column density of log10(N(HI)/cm^-2) = 14.5, exhibits an enhancement along both the disk plane (azimuthal angle phi < 20 degree) and in the polar direction (phi > 70 degree). In contrast, such a bimodal distribution is not observed for higher mass galaxies (9 < log10(M*/Msun) < 11.3). Similarly, the O VI covering fraction (k_OVI), for a threshold of log10(N(OVI)/cm^-2) = 14.0, shows a tentative enhancement along both the projected major and minor axes for low-mass galaxies. In contrast, O VI-bearing gas around higher- mass galaxies appears more uniformly distributed, with no significant azimuthal dependence. Finally, using the halo circular-velocity-normalized pixel-velocity two-point correlation function (TPCF), we find that O VI absorbers are kinematically narrower along the disk plane compared to the polar directions of the host galaxies with similar stellar mass distributions. The observed isotropic distribution of O VI in high-mass halos suggests that its spatial distribution is governed by global halo properties; however, the O VI kinematics retain memory of the site of origin.

AI.tldr: Study finds azimuthal dependence of H I and O VI gas in CGM of low-mass galaxies shows bimodal distribution (enhanced along disk plane and polar directions), while high-mass galaxies show uniform distribution. O VI kinematics differ between disk plane and polar directions.
AI.motivation: To investigate how circumgalactic medium gas distribution and kinematics depend on galaxy orientation (azimuthal angle) and how this varies with galaxy mass, particularly examining whether gas distribution shows preferential alignment with galaxy disk or polar directions.
AI.method: Analyzed 113 isolated galaxies (0.12<z<0.75) including 91 new measurements from MUSEQuBES survey. Measured H I and O VI covering fractions within virial radius for different azimuthal angles. Used halo circular-velocity-normalized pixel-velocity two-point correlation function (TPCF) to analyze O VI kinematics.
AI.result: Low-mass galaxies (7<log10(M*/Msun)<9) show enhanced H I covering fraction along both disk plane (φ<20°) and polar directions (φ>70°). O VI shows similar tentative enhancement. High-mass galaxies (9<log10(M*/Msun)<11.3) show uniform distribution with no azimuthal dependence. O VI absorbers are kinematically narrower along disk plane compared to polar directions.
AI.conclusion: Low-mass galaxies exhibit bimodal CGM gas distribution suggesting different physical origins (disk vs. polar). High-mass galaxies show isotropic O VI distribution governed by global halo properties, though O VI kinematics retain memory of origin site. The results indicate mass-dependent CGM structure and kinematics.
